loans.name: Tata

texts.en:
Tata is a maize farmer from Ango village. As a Babban Gona member, Tata is excited to have access to a trained agronomist and superior inputs that will give him the chance to achieve high yields of up to 8 MT/Ha, 5.5 times higher than the average Nigerian farmer.

Before joining Babban Gona, Tata would have had to sell his maize at harvest, when the price of maize is at it’s lowest, to meet his immediate cash needs. Tata will use this loan to store the maize he harvests, enabling him to delay its sale until a later period in the season when he can obtain the best price for his maize at a premium of up to 37% higher than the market price.

Thanks to the support from Babban Gona’s marketing services, Tata no longer feels the pressure to sell his maize at low harvest prices. With the opportunity to earn up to $2,000/Ha, Tata hopes to realize better yields and plans on using his additional income to acquire more land to put into the Babban Gona program.

loans.use: to buy food and clothing, eliminating pressure to sell maize for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Yahaya

texts.en:
Yahaya is a Babban Gona farmer. Yahaya is excited that Babban Gona offers a lasting solution to ending the cycle of poverty, renewing his dreams of gaining wealth someday.

Traditionally, Yahaya would have had to sell his maize at harvest, a period when maize prices are at their lowest in the market, to meet his immediate cash needs. With this loan, Yahaya can store his maize at harvest and sell it at a future date for up to 37% higher than the market price at harvest.

Benefiting from Babban Gona’s marketing support, Yahaya has the opportunity to generate earnings of up to $2,000/ha. Yahaya is thankful that he no longer has to worry about having no money to pay for his children's school fees and looks forward to using his additional earnings to acquire more land to put into the Babban Gona program.

loans.use: to buy food and clothing, eliminating pressure to sell maize for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Fahda

texts.en:
Fahda is a 48 year-old Lebanese married woman living with her husband and three children, one of whom is still studying. Her husband works as an employee in order to fulfil their family needs and improve their lifestyle.

Today, she is in need of a loan from Kiva's partner Vitas s.a.l. to pay her child's school stationary fees. It will make her very happy to be able to pursue their education suitably and help them secure a brilliant future.

loans.use: to pay her children's school stationary fees.

loans.name: Lina

texts.en: Lina is a 43-year-old married Lebanese woman living with her husband and three children. She cooperates with her husband in order to fulfill their needs. She works as a private teacher in a school. Her husband is an employee in a local company. Today, given that her children will enter school very soon, she is requesting a loan from Kiva partner Vitas s.a.l. to pay school fees. The parents’ only wish is to provide their children with a respectable educational path until graduation.

loans.use: to pay school fees.

loans.name: Imane

texts.en:
Imane is a 27-year-old, Lebanese married woman. She lives with her husband who represents the main source of income for the family. She is very tender and cares a lot about all of her family members.

Today, she is eager to take a loan from Kiva's partner, Vitas. s.a.l., to pay for her brother’s educational fees. She intends to help her brother to provide him with a good education. This is Imane’s first Kiva loan and she wants to express her thanks for it.

loans.use: to pay her brother’s educational fees.

loans.name: Sonia

texts.en: Sonia is a 43 year-old Lebanese married woman and the mother for three children, all of whom are still attending school. They all live with her husband who is the income provider. She states that living costs are becoming very expensive. This is the reason why she is in real need today of borrowing a loan from Kiva partner Vitas s.a.l., which will be used at once to cover her children's study fees. Her first goal is to insure a good educational level for them.

loans.use: to cover her children's study fees.

loans.name: Hannah

texts.en:
Hannah is 36 years old, married to a businessman, and blessed with three children 16, 8, and 4 years old. She has had a clothing business for seven years, currently earning a monthly income of KES. 15,000. She has borrowed KES 25,000 from VisionFund Kenya as her first loan.

Hannah will be using the loan to purchase second-hand clothes. She hopes that the anticipated profit will help her buy food for the family, pay school fees for her kids, add to her savings in her personal account, cover medical care, expand the current business and repay her loan.

Her hopes and dreams for the future are to have a well established clothing business and enjoy a better life with her family.

loans.use: to purchase second-hand clothes.

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret is a 37-year-old food kiosk owner in Kilifi, Kenya. She is a mother of four and has a husband who provides additional income. She has been in this business for the last five years and is doing well.

This is her second loan from VisionFund Kenya to finance her business.

She will use the money to purchase milk, sugar, wheat and maize flour, cooking fat and beans. The anticipated profit will help Margaret to expand and renovate her food kiosk.

Margaret hopes to own a successful business in the future.

loans.use: to purchase milk, sugar, wheat and maize flour, cooking fat and beans

loans.name: Itahiro Tweimukye Group

texts.en:
Nkwabale is a 54-year-old mother of five children, living in Kagadi, Uganda.

She deals in produce, buying and selling. She also does farming and owns a piggery business for additional income, a business she started in 2001 with an aim of making money to be used to look after her family’s increasing demands.

She wishes to achieve her greatest desire of educating her children to the university level. She is challenged by heavy rains and bad roads in the area, making transporting the produce hard.

Nkwabale will use the loan to buy feed for her piglets. She is a member of Itahiro Tweimukye Group where members guarantee each other to get loans since they don’t pledge securities.

loans.use: to buy feed for her piglets.

loans.name: Jemina

texts.en:
Jermima, is aged 47 and reached her elementary school education. She is a single mother and has two children, both of whom attend school. Jermima takes the whole responsibility for her family, therefore, she is working hard to achieve success.

For twelve years, Jermima has been involved in her business in which she sells soft drinks and sachet water as it was the best way to earn an income. She also does housework. Her children help her in selling these products. Jermima sells these products at her residence where customers come from far and near to buy drinks for themselves and friends. Jermima is happy to offer her customers excellent service. She needs this loans to buy drinks and sachet distilled water to sell to customers.

Her dream is to see her children become professionals because she did not have the opportunity to do so.

loans.use: to buy soft drinks and distilled water sachets to sell to customers.

loans.name: Jibrin

texts.en: Jibrin is a maize farmer and Babban Gona member. Anticipating a good harvest this season, Jibrin has the opportunity to attain yields of up to 8MT/Ha, 5.5 times that of the average Nigerian maize farmer. Before joining Babban Gona, Jibrin would have had to sell his maize at harvest, a period when maize prices are at their lowest in the market, to meet his immediate cash needs. With the help of this loan, Jibrin can store his maize and sell it at a future date for up to 37% higher than the market price at harvest. As a Babban Gona member, Jibrin will benefit from marketing support that could see him generate earnings of up to $2000/ha. Jibrin is thankful that he now has the opportunity to improve the life of his children and family and looks forward to using his additional earnings to ensure that all his children get a post-secondary education.

loans.use: To buy food and clothing, eliminating pressure to sell maize for low prices at harvest

loans.name: Mai Anguwa

With the opportunity to earn up to $2000/Ha, Mai Anguwa now has the opportunity to actualize his dream to grow his agriculture business for himself and family members and would like to use this additional income to acquire more land to put into the Babban Gona program.

loans.use: to buy food and clothing, eliminating pressure to sell maize for low prices at harvest .

loans.name: Yakubu

texts.en: Yakubu is a maize farmer and Babban Gona member. Anticipating a good harvest this season, Yakubu has the opportunity to attain yields of up to 8MT/Ha, 5.5 times that of the average Nigerian maize farmer. As a Babban Gona member, Yakubu will benefit from marketing support that could see him generate earnings of up to $2000/ha. Yakubu is thankful that he now has the opportunity to improve the life of his children and family and looks forward to using his additional earnings to ensure that all his children get a post secondary education.

loans.use: to buy food and clothing, eliminating the pressure to sell maize for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Nour

texts.en: Nour is a 28-year-old Lebanese woman, who is married and lives with her husband and two children.  Her husband provides the main source of income for the family in order to enhance their way of living.  Today, Nour hopes to help her children with their education.  For that reason, she wants to take a loan from Vitas s.a.l., a Kiva partner, to pay the last installment of their study fees.  She will be more than happy to see them graduate and achieve their master’s degree.  In the future, she plans to take new Kiva loans to continue to cover their study fees.

loans.use: to pay the last installment of her children's study fees.

loans.name: Wadad

texts.en:
Wadad is a 52 year old Lebanese married woman living with her husband. She is the mother of three children still attending school. Her husband is the main income source for the family. He has worked in the construction field for many years to satisfy the necessities of life and until now he earns a fair income.

Today, she is requesting a loan from Kiva's partner Vitas s.a.l to pay her children’s educational fees. She said that the loan will surely help her to register them for the coming school year. This makes her very happy and eager to borrow from kiva.

loans.use: to pay her children’s educational fees

loans.name: Samira

texts.en: Samira is a 31-year-old married woman from Lebanon. She lives with her husband and four children. All of her children attend school. Her husband works tirelessly to be always ready to ensure her family a good life. Today, she looks to borrow a loan from Kiva partner Vitas s.a.l. to pay her children’s educational fees. This is Samira’s third loan from Kiva and this definitely will help her to ensure them a good education path.

loans.use: to pay her children’s educational fees

loans.name: Michael

texts.en:
Michael is a 30-year-old green grocer in Mishomuhoroni, Kenya. He is a father of two children and has been in this business for the last four years, doing well.

This is his fourth loan to finance his business. Michael will use the loan to purchase vegetables and fruit. The anticipated profit would improve his life and educate his children. He hopes to have a happy family in the future.

loans.use: to purchase vegetables and fruit..

loans.name: Bosco

texts.en:
Bosco used his previous loan to buy a motorcycle for transportation, a business that has seen him increase his income levels. He is a hardworking man, living in Fort Portal Uganda. He has a a liquor store business that he operates eight hours a day. At the same time, he earns a salary that provides him more income.

He is facing the challenge of unpredictable market price changes that do not allow him to earn bigger profits. However, he has a vision of owning a variety of enterprises in which he can earn from one when the other falters.

Bosco needs a loan to buy land on which he can construct a good house for his family.

loans.use: to buy land where he can construct a good house for his family.

loans.name: Suleman

texts.en:
Suleman is a Babban Gona maize farmer. Thanks to Babban Gona’s support, Suleman is thankful that days of poor yields are long gone. As a Babban Gona member, he has the opportunity to achieve yields of up to 8MT/Ha, 5.5 times the yield of the average Nigerian farmer.

Traditionally, Suleman would have had to sell his maize for low prices at harvest to meet his immediate cash needs. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Suleman will store the maize he harvests and delay its sale until a later date in the season when his can obtain a significantly higher price for his maize at a premium up to 37% more than the harvest price.

With the opportunity to earn up to $2,000/Ha, Suleman now has the expects to fulfill his dream to grow his agriculture business for himself and family members. He would like to use his additional income to buy maize grinding machines.

loans.use: to buy food and clothing, eliminating pressure to sell maize for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Alkasim

texts.en: Alkasim is a maize farmer and Babban Gona member.  Anticipating a good harvest this season, Alkasim has the opportunity to attain yields of up to 8MT/hectare, 5.5 times that of the average Nigerian maize farmer.  Before joining Babban Gona, Alkasim would have had to sell his maize at harvest, a period when maize prices are at their lowest in the market, to meet his immediate cash needs.  With the help of this loan, Alkasim can store his maize and sell it at a future date (for a price up to 37% higher than the market price at harvest).  As a Babban Gona member, Alkasim will benefit from marketing support that could see him generate earnings of up to $2,000/hectare.  Alkasim is thankful that he now has the opportunity to improve the life of his children and family and looks forward to using his additional earnings to acquire more land to put into the Babban Gona program.

loans.use: to buy food and clothing, eliminating pressure to sell his maize for low prices at harvest to meet his immediate cash needs.

loans.name: Yau

texts.en:
Yau is a Babban Gona maize farmer. Thanks to Babban Gona’s support, Yau is thankful that days of poor yields are long gone. As a Babban Gona member, he has the opportunity to achieve yields of up to 8MT/Ha, 5.5 times the yield of the average Nigerian farmer.

Traditionally, Yau would have had to sell his maize for low prices at harvest to meet his immediate cash needs. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Yau will store the maize he harvests and delay its sale until a later date in the season when his can obtain a significantly higher price for his maize at a premium up to 37% more than the harvest price.

With the opportunity to earn up to $2,000/Ha, Yau now has the opportunity to fulfill his dream to grow his agriculture business for himself and family members. He would like to use his additional income to diversify his farm and grow other crops.

loans.use: to buy food and clothing, eliminating pressure to sell maize for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Ibrahim

texts.en:
Ibrahim is a maize farmer from Hayin Malam Yako village. As a Babban Gona member, Ibrahim is excited to have access to a trained agronomist and superior inputs that will give him the chance to achieve high yields of up to 8 MT/Ha, 5.5 times higher than the average Nigerian farmer.

Before joining Babban Gona, Ibrahim would have had to sell his maize at harvest, when the price of maize is at it’s lowest, to meet his immediate cash needs. Ibrahim will use this loan to store the maize he harvests, enabling him to delay its sale until a later period in the season when he can obtain the best price for his maize at a premium of up to 37% higher than the market price.

Thanks to the support from Babban Gona’s marketing services, Ibrahim no longer feels the pressure to sell his maize at low harvest prices. With the opportunity to earn up to $2,000/Ha, Ibrahim hopes to realize better yields and plans on using his additional income to ensure that all his children get a post-secondary education.

loans.use: to buy food and clothing, eliminating pressure to sell maize for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita 37, is married and has two children aged sixteen and fifteen years old. The family lives in Bilar, Leyte. She works diligently selling fruits, vegetables and other goods in her store in the local marketplace.

Teresita has applied for a 18,000 PHP loan through Kiva's field partner CEVI to buy groceries for her store such as soft drinks, noodles, biscuits and seasonings. She know that her store’s profits are enough to help support her family and provide better living conditions for it.

Teresita is determined to be successful and to be able to continue paying for the schooling of her two children.

loans.use: to buy groceries for her store such as soft drinks, noodles, biscuits and seasonings.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth is a 51-year-old poultry farmer from Likoni, Kenya. She is a mother of two whose spouse provides additional income for the family and who has done well.

This is her fourth borrowing from VisionFund Kenya. She is taking another loan to finance her business after successfully repaying her previous loans. Elizabeth will use the loan to purchase feed for her poultry. With the anticipated profits, she will be able to repay her loan.

She hopes to have a happy family whose needs are covered in the future.

loans.use: to purchase feed for her poultry.

loans.name: Anzhela

texts.en:
Anzhela lives with her nice family in Dilijan city. She is a mother of three children, two daughters and a son. Her elder daughter is already married, and she lives with her family. The younger daughter is a student, and her son is in the army now, completing his military service.

Anzhela’s husband is now in the Russian Federation. Working there, he sends money home for his family's needs. Anzhela graduated Yerevan State University, and she has a specialty in teaching. For many years, she has worked in her specialty. At the school, she is a teacher of Armenian language and literature.

Anzhela has very serious health problems, and she has to take a lot of medicine in order to control her illness. These medicines are very expensive, and she orders them from the Europe. So, Anzhela asks for this loan of 1,000,000 Armenian drams, as it is time to order her medicine. She has a great lack of financial resources, and the Kiva program is the only way of solving this urgent problem.

Her great and sincere thanks beforehand to all the Kiva lenders for their support.

loans.use: to order and pay for her medicine.

loans.name: Jibrin

texts.en:
Jibrin is a Babban Gona Farmers Organization maize farmer. Thanks to Babban Gona’s support, Jibrin is thankful that days of poor yields are long gone.

As a Babban Gona member, Jibrin has the opportunity to achieve yields of up to 8MT/hectare, 5.5 times the yield of the average Nigerian farmer.

Traditionally, Jibrin would have had to sell his maize for low prices at harvest, to meet his immediate cash needs. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Jibrin will store the maize he harvests and delay its sale until a later date in the season, when he can obtain a significantly higher price for his maize, at a premium of up to 37% beyond the harvest price.

With the opportunity to earn up to USD 2,000/hectare, Jibrin now has the opportunity to actualize his dream, to grow his agriculture business for himself and his family members. He would like to use this additional income to acquire more land to put into the Babban Gona program.

loans.use: to buy food and clothing, eliminating pressure to sell maize for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: In God Group

texts.en:
These people are members of the group called In God in Teshie, Accra, Ghana. This part of the city contains citizens who are very friendly and hardworking. The three dedicated members are together in this group, and they are working hard to make their dreams for better lives come true. They are into plastic products, frozen food, soft drinks and second hand clothing.

Rebecca has one child and is married to a mechanic. In order to make more income for the family, Rebecca sells ladies' tops, straight dresses and skirts. She is asking for a loan to buy more ladies' tops, straight dresses and skirts for resale to her customers. This is her second loan cycle with Kiva, and her sixth loan cycle with ID Ghana.

They promise to repay the loan without fail.

loans.use: to buy more ladies' tops, straight dresses and skirts for resale to her customers.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy more cassava flour to sell.

loans.name: Boldukan

texts.ru: Болдукан, 34 года, замужем, вместе с супругом воспитывают 5 детей. У Болдукан- среднее образование, в качестве дохода для своей семьи Болдукан занимается животноводством, стартовав 10 лет назад, с покупки скота на 15,000 сом (KGS). Благодаря упорному труду Болдукан, в ее хозяйстве на сегодняшний день имеется 2 коровы. Ежемесячный доход составляет 20,000 сом (KGS). В целях дальнейшего развития своего хозяйства, Болдукан обратилась в Банк «Бай –Тушум» за кредитом в сумме 50,000 сом (KGS) на покупку коровы с теленком. Доходы от кредита Болдукан планирует вложить в дальнейшее приумножение количества домашней скотины.
texts.en: Boldukan is 34 years old, married, and has five children. She has a secondary education. To support her family she began an animal husbandry business ten years ago with an initial purchase of 15,000 som (KGS) worth of livestock. Thanks to her persistence she now owns two cows. Her monthly income is 20,000 som (KGS). In order to further develop the business Boldukan is asking Bai Tushum Bank for a 50,000 som (KGS) loan to buy a cow and calf. She plans to invest income from use of the loan into further expanding her livestock headcount.

loans.use: to buy a cow and calf in order to expand her herd.

loans.name: Nokutenda Group

texts.en:
Nokutenda means by faith, this group borrowed a very good name from the Christianity circles. This group consists of four ladies who have an average age of 40 years. Miriam is a member, a woman who appears to be the source of motivation to her counterparts. She is a mother of 4 and is married to a burial society officer, on the far right in the photo.

Miriam has a piggery project in which she started with only 11 pigs, but now she has 45 pigs. She started the project in 2011, her major setback is the capital to buy the stock feeds and more sows.
Miriam who is helping her husband to feed the family, confessed that she hopes that Thrive will help her since many potential Microfinance institutions were just giving her false promises. Miriam hopes to be a member of the Zimbabwe Pig Industry board (ZPID) but she had no finance to join such association. Miriam hopes her sales will increase if she becomes a member of the association, because she will be able to sell her porkers at a regulated price.

Miriam wants a loan from Thrive so that she will be able to buy stock feeds and boost her business, being a woman of such creativeness and venture in this kind of business speaks volumes her hardworking character.

loans.use: to buy feed stocks for her pigs.

loans.name: Mohammad

texts.en: Mohammad is 29, single and has a small weddings and funerals pavilions project that he started to help his father with the family income. He is requesting a 6000 EGP loan to buy new wood, cloth and chairs to expand his project.

loans.use: to buy new wood, cloth and chairs for his weddings and funerals hired equipment business .

loans.name: Thea's Group

texts.en: Thea’s group live in a rural village in Kandal province in Cambodia. Thea makes a living cultivating rice and he also does extra work as factory laborer to support his family. In their village there is no reliable access to safe, clean drinking water. Having a water filter at home will help each of these women and men to safeguard the health of their families and save money on medical expenses and save time collecting fuel and boiling water.

loans.use: to buy a water filter to provide safe drinking water for their family.	.

loans.name: Maa Mangala Shg Group

texts.en:
Runubala is a 29-year-old hardworking and optimistic housewife and is a differently abled lady. She lives with her husband and their five-year-old son in a small village in Angul, Odisha. She started her own sewing business so that she could provide her son with a better education than the primary schooling she had.

Runubala's husband is a farmer whose earnings are very scant. Runubala supplements her husband's income by sewing and selling clothes to her villagers. She supports her family with the income she earns by sewing clothes like dresses, blouses, shirts, frocks, etc. Her small business brings a good monthly income and she diligently saves a small part of this, running her home with the rest of her income supported by the income her husband brings in.

Aware that these savings will be insufficient, she is working to increase her business earning potential. To improve her productivity and take on more customers, she wants to buy a new and better sewing machine. To put this plan into action, Runubala needs access to funds. So, she along with her group member, is requesting a loan of 24,000 INR from Kiva via Peoples Forum, who gives microloans to needy hardworking women like her to start or enlarge micro businesses.

Runubala will use her portion of the loan to buy a new sewing machine and hopes she will be able to cater to more customers. She will use this significant boost in her savings to educate her son and invest in the further growth of her business.

She expresses her gratitude to her lenders. Runubala is standing on the right hand side in the photograph.

loans.use: to buy a new sewing machine

loans.name: Tijjani

texts.en:
Tijjani is a maize farmer and Babban Gona member. Anticipating a good harvest this season, Tijjani has the opportunity to attain yields of up to 8MT/ha, 5.5 times that of the average Nigerian maize farmer.

Before joining Babban Gona, Tijjani would have had to sell his maize at harvest, a period when maize prices are at their lowest in the market, to meet his immediate cash needs. With the help of this loan, Tijjani can store his maize and sell it at a future date for up to 37% more than the market price at harvest. As a Babban Gona member, Tijjani will benefit from the marketing support that could see him generate earnings of up to $2000/ha.

Tijjani is thankful that he now has the opportunity to improve the life of his children and family, and he looks forward to using his additional earnings to acquire more land to put into the Babban Gona program.

loans.use: To buy food and clothing, eliminating pressure to sell maize for low prices at harvest

loans.name: Hanady

texts.en:
Hanady is a 25-year-old married mother of four children. She has been working as a hairdresser and provides makeup services from her house for six years.
In addition to the beauty services she provides, Hanady sells beauty cosmetics, perfumes and bags to fulfill her customers needs, and improve her family's living.
Hanady is acquiring a YOUTH loan from Kiva's field partner Al Majmoua to purchase special Autumn and winter special offer collection.
She hopes that in the future she can move her business outside her house and attract more customers.

loans.use: to purchase an autumn and winter special offer cosmetics collection.

loans.name: Alikanjelu

texts.en:
Alikanjelu is a hardworking man with five children, living in Kyenjojo, Uganda. His business is buying and selling, products, mainly maize, beans and coffee.

With his savings from his products business, he put up a building to rent to supplement his income for his sustainability and that of his family. His challenges are unpredictable weather changes and price fluctuations for products. Alikanjelu needs the loan to buy more maize to sell

His personal dream is to build a permanent home for his family and to educate his children.

loans.use: to buy more maize to sell.

loans.name: Manuel De Jesus

texts.es:
Manuel, de 47 años de edad, estudio hasta tercer grado, está casado, su esposa es ama de casa y tienen dos hijos.

Manuel, ha trabaja desde muy pequeño, su primer trabajo fue junto a su padre sembrando granos básicos y criando ganado; actualmente tiene más de 15 años de trabajar como albañil y este oficio lo aprendió gracias a uno de sus tíos, pero siempre continua sembrando maíz y criando ganado de repasto.  

El crédito lo necesita para comprar ganado de repasto.

El sueño de Manuel, es mejorar su vivienda y tener un terreno propio donde sembrar y pastar sus animales.
texts.en:
Manuel, 47 years old, studied up to the third grade and is married. His wife works at home and they have two children.

Manuel has worked since he was very small. His first job was to work with his father sowing basic grains and raising cattle. At present, he has spent more than 15 years as a cement mason, a skill he learned thanks to one of his uncles. But Manuel has continued to sow corn and raise cattle in the pasture.

Manuel needs the loan to purchase additional cattle to raise.

His dream is to make improvements on their home, and to have his own land where he can sow crops and raise farm animals.

loans.use: to purchase cattle to pasture.

loans.name: Mairamhon

texts.ru: Майрамхон, 48 лет, замужем, имеет 3 детей. У нее среднее образование, 11 лет занимается сельским хозяйством,  благодаря неустанному труду и терпению, Майрамхон успешно увеличила размеры своего небольшого бизнеса. В хозяйстве есть 3 коровы, 6 овец. Майрамхон в целях дальнейшего развития своего бизнеса и приумножения прибыли, обратилась в Банк «Бай-Тушум» за кредитом в сумме 50,000 сом (KGS) на покупку нетели. На доходы от кредита Майрамхон хочет и дальше развивать бизнес.
texts.en: Mairamhon is 48 years old, married, and has three children. She has a secondary education and has worked in agriculture for eleven years. Thanks to her tireless work and endurance she has been successful in growing her small business. She now owns three cows and six sheep. In order to further develop her business and increase her income she asked Bai Tushum Bank for a 50,000 som (KGS) loan to buy a heifer. Mairamhon plans to use income from use of the loan to further develop her business.

loans.use: to buy a heifer to increase her livestock headcount.

loans.name: Yoeun

texts.en:
Yoeun, 39, is a resident in Battambang province. She is married and blessed with three dependent daughters, two of whom attend school and the remaining one is under the age of school. She earns main source of income from growing rice while her husband works as soldier. She also grows vegetables in her garden to sell for additional income. She has been involved in farming business for 12 years. This family’s income is about USD22 per day and Yoeun can save approximately about USD15 each day. Not enough water to supply in rice field and pests are the main challenges to her rice crop.

This sixth-cycle client is now applying for a loan from VisionFund; past loans have enabled her to keep a daughter of her in school until she graduates from high school and meet family’s needs on time. For this loan, Yoeun will use it to pay for school fees and buy school supplies for her daughter who is in university. She hopes that her daughter can graduate from university and have bright future.

loans.use: to pay for school fees and buy school supplies for her daughter in university, so that she can graduate and have a bright future.

loans.name: Anecita

texts.en:
Anecita is a loyal member of CCT Credit Cooperative in Tigbauan, Iloilo for ten years already. She has gained a lot of tips on business handling and strengthened her faith in God through the cooperative’s weekly fellowship. She’s praying that her children would opt to become cooperative members, so they could also enjoy its benefits.

Anecita is a 59-year-old widow who was able to rise above the odds. She has raised her children well through fattening of hogs and buying and selling of rice. She chose these enterprises because it provides food for the community. Although the return of investment in hog raising comes after several months, she is happy to provide reasonably priced meat for her community.

At this stage, Anecita has a slight problem. She has already advanced considerable amount of capital for feeds and vitamins, but her hogs are not yet ready for selling. She has run over her budget, hence she is requesting for PhP 50,000 loan. Aside from feed, she will also buy more sacks of rice to sell. She hopes that you are willing to extend help so she can increase her profit and boost her savings. She is looking forward to renovating her house if her savings suffices.

She shares her experiences and aspirations to her co-fellowship* members at CCT Credit Cooperative who regularly meet once a week to share stories about their life and businesses and to draw strength from the fellowship and the Word of God.

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to buy feeds and vitamins for hogs; plus sacks of rice for retail

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to increase on her amount of chickens and chicken feed.

loans.name: Fatima

texts.en:
Fatima is a 35-year-old married mother of five children, who has been supporting her husband in their bakery for thirteen years.
Fatima is a hard working woman, she is working hard to improve and develop her family's living. She is acquiring a loan from Kiva's field partner Al Majmoua to start an additional income business which she will run from her house through purchasing new Autumn and winter clothes to sell them.
She is very optimistic about this loan, and she hopes that in the future she can open a specialized clothes selling shop.

loans.use: to start an additional income business which she will operate from her house, through purchasing new autumn and winter clothes to sell.

loans.name: Zhibek

texts.ru: Жибек успешно погасила свой кредит, использовав его по назначению. Она благодарна Фонду Кива и всем, кто помог ей в финансировании.  На сегодняшний день в хозяйстве есть 13 овец. Ежемесячный доход составляет 13,000 сом (KGS). В целях дальнейшего развития своего хозяйства, Жибек обратилась в Банк «Бай –Тушум» за кредитом в сумме 20,000 сом (KGS) на покупку овец. Доходы от кредита Жибек планирует вложить в дальнейшее приумножение количества домашней скотины и ремонт дома.
texts.en: Zhibek successfully repaid her previous loan, having used it as planned. She thanks Kiva and all who helped with the financing. She currently owns 13 sheep and her monthly income is 13,000 som (KGS). In order to further develop the business Zhibek is asking Bai Tushum Bank for a 20,000 som (KGS) loan to buy sheep. She plans to invest income from use of the loan into further increasing her livestock headcount and making repairs to her home.

loans.use: to purchase some sheep and invest in her business

loans.name: Adamu

texts.en:
Adamu is a Babban Gona Farmers Organization maize farmer. Thanks to Babban Gona’s support, Adamu is thankful that days of poor yields are long gone.

As a Babban Gona member, he has the opportunity to achieve yields of up to 8MT/hectare, 5.5 times the yield of the average Nigerian farmer.

Traditionally, Adamu would have had to sell his maize for low prices at harvest to meet his immediate cash needs. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Adamu will store the maize he harvests and delay its sale until a later date in the season, when he can obtain a significantly higher price for his maize, at a premium of up to 37% beyond the harvest price.

With the opportunity to earn up to USD 2,000/hectare, Adamu now has the opportunity to actualize his dream to grow his agriculture business for himself and his family members. He would like to use this additional income to provide employment on his farm to members of his community.

loans.use: to buy food and clothing, eliminating pressure to sell maize for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Maa Hingula Shg Group

texts.en:
Kumari is a 45-year-old single mother with two daughters, ages 18 and 20 years old. She is engaged in the activity of weaving handkerchiefs. Her younger daughter helps her weave them. Her elder daughter works as a daily labourer in her village. The financial condition of the family is not good because Kumari 's husband left her at the most crucial time, when she needed him the most.

She buys raw materials like cotton, thread and colours from a dealer and gives the finished goods to him. In return, she gets only the labour cost, which is very little. Kumari has a plan to buy raw materials directly from the market and sell her finished products in the market. Doing so will increase her income.

Kumari, along with her other group members, has requested a loan of 36,000 Indian rupees. She will use her portion of the loan amount to purchase raw materials for weaving handkerchiefs. She has a dream that her daughters will get married into a good house and that she can save some money for her family’s future.

loans.use: to purchase raw materials for weaving handkerchiefs

loans.name: Verro  Akou

texts.fr: Agée de 34 ans et mère de quatre enfants, Verro est une femme mariée qui vit à Baguida. Verro  frit des poissons et le revend en parcourant les quartiers environnant. Dans le souci d’accroitre son commerce et de maximiser son profit, Verro se rend quatre fois par mois au marché et sollicite ce crédit pour commander des cartons de poissons frais en vue de bien vendre afin de faire usage du bénéfice qui en résultera pour inscrire tous ses enfants dans des écoles de bons établissement scolaire.
texts.en: Verro, aged 34, is the mother of four children. A married woman, she lives in Baguida. She fries fish and resells them by going about nearby neighborhoods. Concerned about growing her business and maximizing her profit, Verro goes to the market four times a month and is requesting this loan to order boxes of fresh fish in order to do well in her sales. She could then use the resulting profits to enroll her children into good schools.

loans.use: to purchase 4 boxes of fresh fish

loans.name: Rehema

texts.en:
Rehema is a married woman. She has four children, all of whom attend school. Rehema owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

Rehema has operated a firewood selling business, selling from home to her neighbours and passersby. She faces stiff competition from other operators in her business.

She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business. With the KES 50,000, she wants to purchase bundles of firewood for resale.

loans.use: to purchase bundles of firewood for resale.

loans.name: Kanga

texts.en:
Kanga is a married woman with five children, one of whom attends school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water.

She has operated a farming business for the past 20 years. She wants to invest in her farming business. With the loan, she plans to purchase seeds and fertilizers to do farming in her business.

loans.use: to purchase seeds and fertilizers to do farming in her business.

loans.name: Akossiwa Marie

texts.fr: Veuve et âgée de 62 ans, Akossiwa est une femme qui vit à Baguida. Avec onze enfants à sa charge, Akossiwa est une revendeuse des objets en plastique. Akossiwa s’approvisionne trois fois par mois au marché et le revend de quartier en quartier. Akossiwa sollicite ce prêt pour commander des douzaines des unités de sceaux  et de bassines en plastiques  en vue de mieux revendre puis de pouvoir  satisfaire parfaitement les attentes de ses clients et réaliser une bonne marge bénéficiaire pour subvenir aux charges et besoins quotidiens de sa famille.
texts.en: Akossiwa is a 62-year-old widow living in Baguida. With eleven children to support, she is a seller of plasticware. She gets her supplies at the market three time a month and resells by going from neighborhood to neighborhood. Akossiwa is requesting this loan to order dozens of units of plastic pails and tubs with the aim of doing better in her sales and satisfying fully the expectations of her customers. She would then realize a good profit to meet the day-to-day needs of her family.

loans.use: to purchase 25 units of plastic pails and 6 plastic tubs

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret is a single mother of one child, who attends school. She rents a house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food.

For the past two years, she has operated a clothing sales business, selling from door to door to her neighbours and passersby. She faces a major challenge of high cost of transportation.

She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business. With the loan of KES 20,000 that she is requesting, she wants to purchase bales of clothes for resale.

loans.use: to purchase bales of clothes for resale

loans.name: Lorena

texts.en:
Lorena is married;a woman who stands out for searching for any possible way to obtain a resource that will allow her to feed her family. Six years ago she began working on their own farm to make a living.Her husband is a fisherman who sells fishes in their town. She thanks God for the opportunity of having a farm as their main source of income.

Based on this success, Lorena is asking for a loan from GDMPC micro credit to purchase fertilizer for her vegetables . In the future, she wants to improve the general living of the entire family.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer for her vegetables

loans.name: Elsa

texts.en:
Elsa, 38, wishes that her variety store will progress someday, thus she exerts her best effort to make it stable. She lives in Guimbal, Iloilo together with her husband Jose, a welder. They are fervently praying for a child.

They are living in a community where people are quite familiar with each other. Therefore Elsa finds it difficult to refuse her neighbors who pay late for the goods they get from her store. This practice shakes the stability of her business. To help cover her collectibles, she requests for additional capital of PHP 15,000 to buy more items for her inventory. It will improve her profit and will help sustain their everyday needs. It will also contribute some steps towards her dream of enjoying a little comfort in the near future. She hopes that if their first child arrives, she has enough savings to support his/her needs.

Elsa prays for good health always and a happy family someday. She commits herself to CCT Credit Cooperative’s vision to alleviate poverty and she regularly meets with her co-fellowship* members every week to share stories of her life and business and to draw strength and inspiration from the fellowship and the Word of God. *All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to buy more items for her inventory

loans.name: Janet

texts.en:
Janet, 41, wakes up very early in the morning and goes to sleep late at night because she has to look after her “sari-sari” (variety) store located in Tigbauan, Iloilo. Some customers buy as early as 4:30am or as late as 11:30pm; and she has to meet their needs or else her business will fail due to competition within the area. Her husband, Brian, who drives their tricycle takes a turn in watching over the store after his work.

Janet also retails rice for additional income. She has to maximize all their resources because she has children who are entering college soon. It’s not a joke to support the college expenses in the Philippines, because it’s really pocket-draining. Hence, Janet aspires to obtain additional loan worth PHP 12,000 which she can use to buy more dry goods, grocery items, and softdrinks to enhance her inventory. Hopefully it can ease up her family’s financial burden with the expected increase on her sales and profit. Regarding their tricycle, she will also set aside some amount to pay for its maintenance.

Janet is a faithful member of CCT Credit Cooperative and she regularly meets with her co-fellowship* members every week to share stories of her life and business and to draw strength and inspiration from the fellowship and the Word of God. *All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to buy more dry goods, grocery items, and softdrinks

loans.name: Apolinia

texts.en:
As a married parent of two children, Apolinia works hard to support her family.

She has a fish vending business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from vegetable vending. Apolinia is borrowing PHP 4000 through NWTF to buy assorted of fish to sell to her local market for her fish vending business.

She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy assorted of fish to sell to her local market

loans.name: Fred

texts.en:
Fred is 27 years old and married with four children ranging in age from 6 to 10 years. All attend school in Hoima, Uganda.

He operates a retail shop, predominantly selling general merchandise such as salt and sugar among other items. In order to supplement his income, Fred owns a piggery unit that has seen him raise his income to support his family.

Fred has limited capital, which hinders his desires. He hopes to grow his business; thus he is seeking a credit facility to buy more items like salt, sugar, bread, etc. to sell.

loans.use: to buy more items like salt, sugar, bread, etc. to sell.

loans.name: Sai Baba Shg Group

texts.en:
Kuni is a 52-year-old single mother sitting in the middle in the photograph. She hails from a small village of Angul, Odisha, India.

Life was very tough for her after her husband left her alone. All the burdens of her family came to her shoulders. But she never broke; she was always rock strong in order to move on and lead a happy life with her only son.

Kuni is currently engaged in a poultry farming business and works hard in order to meet the household needs. However, due to a lack of financial resources, Kuni is unable to provide a higher education to her only son.

She, along with her other group members, is requesting a loan amount of 36,000 INR. Kuni will use her portion of the loan amount to pay the course fees for her son's ITI course. The loan amount will help her son to pursue his higher education smoothly and efficiently.

Kuni is eagerly awaiting your kind help.

loans.use: to pay the course fees for her son's ITI course

loans.name: Success Group

texts.en:
Success group is just pregnant with meaning because of its name. Not many will need a dictionary meaning of success if they come in contact with the members of this group. The group consists of ladies who are bread winners in their families. Olivia, a widow and mother of four (far right in the photo) was very delighted to get the chance to form a group that would lead her to her first formal loan.

Olivia is in a masculine industry of making bricks, dura wall materials and pillars. Her business started slowly but with time she managed to acquire all the equipment needed in this industry. She was even able to buy a stand using her profits. Olivia has gone too far in this trade, that it is now difficult to talk of best security walls in her locality without mentioning her name. However regardless of the fact that she is well known she still does not have enough capacity to supply all her clients, she is pained on countless times as she waves goodbye to some potential customers.
Olivia hopes a loan from Thrive will enlarge her business empire, she needs to acquire more brick molds, pillar design molds and an alternative water supply source preferably a tank.

loans.use: to acquire more brick molds, pillar design molds and an alternative water supply source, preferably a tank.

loans.name: Nary's Group

texts.en: Nary’s group live in a rural village in Kandal province in Cambodia. Nary works as police and she also does extra work as seller and driver to support her family. In their village there is no reliable access to safe, clean drinking water. Having a water filter at home will help each of these women to safeguard the health of their families and save money on medical expenses and save time collecting fuel and boiling water.

loans.use: to buy a water filter to provide safe drinking water for their family.	.

loans.name: Akpéné

texts.fr: Akpéné est une femme mariée résidant à Adidogomé avec quatre enfants à charge. Akpéné est une revendeuse de charbon de bois qui s’approvisionne trois  fois par mois au marché et le revend à la devanture de son domicile. Pour financer son achat, Akpéné  nécessite ce prêt pour commander des sacs de charbon de bois en vue de mieux revendre puis de réaliser plus de bénéfice et soutenir son mari dans les charges de la famille et permettre une bonne éducation à leurs enfants.
texts.en: Akpéné is a married woman residing in Adidogomé with four children in her care. She is a retailer of charcoal and gets her supplies at the market three time a month. She resells in front of her home. To finance her purchase, Akpéné needs this loan to order sacks of charcoal with the aim of having better sales and making more profit to support her husband in covering family expenses. This would allow her children a good education.

loans.use: to purchase 8 sacks of charcoal

loans.name: Muhammad Shafique

texts.en:
M.Shafique owns a furniture business in Karachi. Aged 42, he is hardworking and honest. Not only has he gained 11 years of experience he has also managed to grow and improve his business, employed a few workers and increasing his client base.

He makes a variety of furniture with different types of wood. Carving on furniture is very usual and liked in Pakistan. He makes bed sets, sofa sets, chairs, dinning tables, tables etc. He uses different varieties and qualities of woods to make furniture.

He currently plans to enhance his business further by taking more orders and making more variety of furniture. He has therefore requested for a loan of PKR 150,000 to buy wood for making furniture.
Father of a daughter, he makes sure to give her a better quality of life, she is school going and does well at school.

loans.use: to buy wood for making furniture.

loans.name: Kuruthumu

texts.en:
Kuruthum, who is in her late 20's, is married with three kids; one of them is small and the others are still in school. She has been a food vendor for five years now. She works from 6am to 10pm daily and is able to make a good profit per month.

This will be Kuruthum's third loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. She used the previous loans to increase her cooking ingredients for her mamalishe store and has managed to pay back all her loans successfully. She is doing great. She used the profit to pay school fees for her two kids, make loan repayments, take care of her family and buy a plot. She will use this loan to restock the out-of-stock items in her mamalishe store. She dreams of expanding her business.

Kuruthum will be accountable for paying back her loan.

loans.use: to restock the out-of-stock items in her mamalishe store.

loans.name: Carmelita

texts.en: Carmelita earns an income from her gardening production business. She is from Misom,Baliangao, and has been gardening for more than twelve years, earning enough money to sustain her living expenses. Carmelita has successfully repaid her previous loan, which was used for farm fertilization. She always finds ways to augment her earnings. Recently, Carmelita took a new loan to finance banana replanting costs. Carmelita plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: to finance banana replanting costs

loans.name: Elne

texts.en:
Elnie is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a general store business in the Philippines.

She is borrowing PHP 30000 through NWTF to buy additional items to sell like chips, milk, sugar, eggs, etc for her general store business.

Elnie has been in this business for 7 years. Elnie earns more income from food vending.

She successfully paid back her previous loan, and now she has requested an additional loan to further build her business.

Elnie has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams to save money to expand her business in the future.

loans.use: to buy additional items to sell like chips, milk, sugar, eggs, etc.

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en:
Beatrice is a married woman with three biological children, of whom two attend school. She also takes care of four dependents who are her relatives.

She works seven days a week because of the nature of her business in Kamwenge, Uganda. She previously became a Hofokam borrower after borrowing UGX 1,000,000 initially to add more bulls to her farm.

She intended to start her own business to educate her children and have an improved standard of living, but she did not have enough capital after trying to get some money from her relatives, who also had their own problems. The little she got from them was not enough to start her dream business.

She then approached Hofokam to borrow UGX 1,000,000 to add more cows to her farm because her additional agriculture and second-hand clothes businesses are too seasonal and unreliable.

loans.use: to add more cows to her farm.

loans.name: Jenelie

texts.en:
Jenelie is 34 years old, married with seven children, four of whom in school.

She works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 30000 loan through NWTF to buy items to sell like canned goods, sugar, milk, coffee, etc.

Jenelie has borrowed and paid 12 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for 4 years and also earns an income from selling fish.

She aspires to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy items to sell like canned goods, sugar, milk, coffee, etc

loans.name: Nenita

texts.en:
Nenita is 43 years old, married with eight children.

Nenita works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 4000 loan through NWTF to purchase more groceries to sell like canned goods, noodles, spices, milk, drinks, coffee, bread, snack foods and etc.

She has been running the general store for 10 years and also earns an income from pig fattening and food vending.

Nenita aspires to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase more groceries to sell like canned goods, noodles, spices, milk, drinks, coffee, bread, snack foods and etc

loans.name: Goreth

texts.en:
Goreth is 41 years a resident of Magiri in Rakai district, single mother with 2 children all completed school. Gorreth deals in growing of passion fruits which she started in 2005. And also she grows coffee.

She works 6 days of the week and 12 hours per day and started this business with the aim of supplementing on her daily income and to be able to look after her family.
Gorreth wants a loan of UGX2,000,000/= to buy manure so that she can increase her yields. Her customers are people from different areas in town and passion fruit traders. However her challenges are inadequate capital to expand the business and competition.
Gorreth is a hard working and focused lady.

loans.use: to improve her passion fruit garden by buying pesticides and organic manure.

loans.name: Felicia's Group

texts.en:
This group composed of five women was created during the first loan cycle of ID-Ghana, Teshie branch and it brings together members who all come from the same group and are united by good social and professional relations. They are into the sale of porridge, charcoal, decoration design, rice, pastries, palm oil, beans, gari (cassava flour) and groceries.

Evelyn, the featured borrower, is a married woman age 43 and the mother of two children, both boys who are going to school. She works at selling palm oil, beans, and gari (cassava flour) to her customers.

With her new loan portion of GHS 1,500, she is going to buy palm oil, beans, and gari (cassava flour) to sell to her customers. She has a good deal of experience since she has been in this business for a long time. The profit from her activity will allow her to cover the food and healthcare needs of her children and add to her savings account with ID-Ghana. This is her fisrt loan with Kiva and fifth with ID-Ghana.

loans.use: to buy palm oil, beans and gari (cassava flour) to sell to her customers.

loans.name: Asha

texts.en:
Asha is a married woman with five children, four of whom attend school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water.

She has operated a retail shop business for the past 15 years, selling household consumables like wheat flour, maize flour, and sugar. She faces major challenges with transportation and seasonality in her business.

With the loan she is requesting, she wants to purchase stock of sugar, rice, maize flour and wheat flour. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase stock of sugar, rice, maize flour and wheat flour

loans.name: Tupo Pamoja Group

texts.en:
Bakari is in his early 40s and is married with five children. Four of the children are at school and one of them is still small. He has been running a retail shop for 10 years now. He works from 8am to 10pm daily and is able to make a small monthly profit.

This will be Bakari's third loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. He used the previous loans to increase the shop inventory and has paid back all his loans successfully. He used the profit to pay school fees, to repay loan and cover household expenses. He will use this loan to increase the fast-moving items in his retail shop. He dreams of expanding his shop into a supermarket.

Bakari will share this loan with his loan group Tupo Pamoja, which consists of two members who will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to increase the fast-moving items in his retail shop.

loans.name: Mwanasha

texts.en:
Mwanasha is a married mother of three children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are school fees and household consumables.

For over ten years, she has operated an open air food selling business, selling from home to her neighbours and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her place of business.

With the KES 10,000 she wants to purchase bundles of wheat flour, maize flour, tea leaves, and cooking fat. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase bundles of wheat flour, maize flour, tea leaves, and cooking fat.

loans.name: Mohammed

texts.en: Mohammed is a new client with the institution, married with four children, three of whom are attending school. Mohammed is a fish monger in the Rukungiri town area. As his major source of income, he has done this business for over 18 years. However, he has been hindered by limited capital to expand his business. Therefore, he decided to join UGAFODE for financial assistance to expand his business. Mohammed has applied for a loan of 2,000,000 UGX to buy more fish so that he can make more profits. He thanks UGAFODE for the financial assistance which will enable him to expand his business and be able to meet all his family financial needs, especially school fees, and sustain his business.

loans.use: to buy fish to sell.

loans.name: In God Group

texts.en:
The group "In God" will begin its eighth cycle with ID-Ghana. As part of its branch loan provision, the group comprises four members, represented by Stella, a member of the group. The members' businesses vary: cooked rice and stew, charcoal, kids' slippers, and gari (cassava flour). This loan will benefit their small micro-businesses.

Stella joined ID-Ghana through an invitation from a friend who is a customer of the institution. Currently, she has a business selling cooked rice and stew to her customers. This loan is intended to increase her income. She will buy rice, vegetables, other ingredients, and charcoal to prepare rice and stew, which she will sell to her customers in the city of Accra.

This form of work enables her to have a job and resources to support herself economically. When asked what she likes about ID-Ghana, she says she likes the training and the savings that the institution offers.

loans.use: to buy rice, vegetables, other ingredients, and charcoal to prepare rice and stew, which she will sell to her customers in the city of Accra.

loans.name: Nelfa

texts.en:
Nelfa, 47, is engaged in a “sari-sari” or variety store business in her community in Tigbauan, Iloilo. She sells various commodities that are essential to the everyday living of the people in her area. These include sachets of shampoo, toothpaste, soap, snacks, candies, bread, repacked condiments and many other items. Basically, she earns enough to provide some of their basic needs but there are times that it’s not sufficient. Thus, she also ventured into load retailing or electronic load for cellphones. It is also a viable business because most cellphone owners use the prepaid plan and only a few subscribe to a postpaid plan. In prepaid arrangements, a person can budget his load usage because he can buy as low as 10-pesos worth of load. Nelfa and her farmer husband, Joesen, work persistently for their only child. They are not content to just make a daily living because they aspire to save more for the future.

With this forward-looking mindset, Nelfa wants to make her business more profitable. She would like to avail a loan amounting to PHP 10,000 to buy assorted groceries, snack items, and soft drinks for her store. She will also set aside some amount for her e-loading business. She is hoping that additional income from this loan will not only sustain their everyday needs, but will also boost her savings for the future. Someday she wants to see her business grow into a big grocery store.

She draws inspiration from her co-fellowship* members who meet every week to share stories of their life and business and to draw strength from the Word of God.

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to buy assorted groceries, snack items, and soft drinks.

loans.name: Erenia Aleykina

texts.es:
El talento de Erenia por la administración de proyectos, actividades y principalmente empresas, llevaron a esta joven de tan solo veinte años de edad, a sentirse atraída por la licenciatura en Administración de Empresas. Actualmente no solo está a punto de finalizar esta etapa estudiando los sábados, sino también se independizó económicamente trabajando desde hace más de un año.
Erenia cuenta con el apoyo de su padre, quien trabaja para una empresa, y de su madre quien es costurera. Por lo que se siente respalda en la decisión de solicitar un préstamo para pagar su curso de titulación, de manera que tendrá la oportunidad de obtener su título y optar por un mejor puesto de trabajo. En sus planes está culminar sus estudios y mejorar su posición laboral.
texts.en: Erenia's talent for project administration, for activities and specially for companies, made this young woman - only 20 years old - be attracted to study a bachelors in Business Administration. Currently, she is not only almost finishing this career by studying on Saturdays, but she has also become financially independent by working for more than a year. Erenia has the support of her father who works for a company, and of her mother who is a seamstress. Therefore, she feels supported in her decision to request a loan to pay for her certification class, and in this way she will have the opportunity to obtain her title and the option of a better job. Her plans include finishing her studies and improving her work situation.

loans.use: to pay for her certification class.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy furniture to use in her restaurant.

loans.name: Jariatu

texts.en:
This is 37-year-old Jariatu. She is married and has two children, aged 16 and 10.

In 2007, Jariatu established her used bags business. Her business is located in a low-cost market, and her main customers are the general public. Working 6 days a week and 8 hours a day, she earns about SLL 1,000,000 every month from this business.

She would like a loan in the amount of SLL 5,000,000. Jariatu requires a loan in order to purchase one bale of ladies bags, one bale of school bags, etc. for resale. She hopes that this loan will support her to increase her profit margin.

In the future, Jariatu plans to educate her children up to university level. The challenges she faces in her business are financial constraints, and the cost of goods increase in the market due to inflation of prices. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to purchase one bale of ladies' bags, one bale of school bags, etc. for resale.

loans.name: Monica Alxandra

texts.es: Monica es soltera tiene 20 años de edad y un hijo de 4 meses se dedica a la crianza y comercializacion de cerdos el dinero lo invertira en compra de balanceado para mejorar la calidad de los cerdos ella quiere llegar a tener una buena solvencia economica para su hijo en sus tiempos libres se dedica a jugar basket ball.
texts.en: Monica is 20 years old. She is single and the mother of a 4 month old son. She works raising and selling pigs. She will invest the money in the purchase of balanced feed to improve the quality of her pigs. She wants to achieve a good economic solvency for her son. In her spare time she plays basketball.

loans.use: to buy balanced feed.

loans.name: Freddy Tobias

texts.es:
FREDDY ES UN CHICO CON VARIAS METAS POR CUMPLIR VIVE CON SUS PAPAS EN LA COMUNIDAD DE FACUNDO VELA, CANTON GURANDA, PROVINCIA BOLIVAR, Y SE DEDICA ESPECIALMENTE A  LA VENTA DE SERVICIO DE ATENCION DE INTERNET, MEDIANTE EL USO DE ESTE CREDITO DESEA LA IMPLEMENTACION DEL INTERNET, PARA LA COMPRA DE EQUIPOS INFORMATICOS.

EL SUEÑO DE FREDDY ES DE MEJORAR COMPLETAMENTE EL SERVICIO DE INTERNET.

DURANTE SU TIEMPO LIBRE, FREDDY MEZCLA MUSICA PARA ALEGRAR SU VIDA.
texts.en:
Freddy is a young man with many goals he wants to accomplish. He lives with his parents in the community of Facundo Vela in the district of Guranda in the Bolivar Province. He works in internet customer service. With this loan he hopes to set up internet service in order to purchase computers. 

Freddy's dream is to completely improve internet service. In his free time he mixes music in order to enjoy life.

loans.use: IMPLEMENTACION DEL INTERNET, PARA LA COMPRA DE EQUIPOS INFORMATICOS

loans.name: Victor Walter

texts.es: Victor es un hombre trabajador de 38 años que vive junto a su pareja y sus tres hijos en la localidad rural de San Basilio, que está ubicada en Arequipa. Él se dedica a múltiples actividades, trabaja como jornalero realizando trabajos agrícolas, cultiva alfalfa orgánica y cría ganado vacuno orgánico, poniendo siempre mucha atención en el cuidado y en la alimentación que les brinda, que está constituida por la alfalfa orgánica que cultiva. Solicita el micro crédito para poder comprar dos vacas orgánicas, espera que su leche sea vendida a un mejor precio al ser orgánica. En el futuro espera poder mejorar las condiciones de vida de su familia y ofrecerles estabilidad económica.
texts.en:
Victor is 38-year-old, hard-working man. He lives with his partner and 3 children in the rural area of San Basilio, which is located in Arequipa.

He has multiple jobs such as agricultural day laborer, cultivating organic alfalfa and breeding organic cows, always placing much attention on the care and nutrition he provides for them, which is made from the organic alfalfa he cultivates.

He is soliciting a loan so he can buy two organic cows; he hopes their milk will be sold at better prices because it is organic.

In the future, he hopes to offer his family an improved quality of life and economic stability.

loans.use: buy two organic cows.

loans.name: Juan Isabel

texts.es:
Juan es un hombre de cincuenta y un años de edad, lleno de energía y con mucho amor por el campo, padre de cuatro hijos, a los cuales les ha enseñado a ser agradecidos con la tierra y con los animales, juntos han sacado adelante su negocio de producción de granos básicos y productos derivados de la leche de vaca. 
para brindarle a sus vacas un buen alimento Juan solicita un financiamiento que planea usar para comprar alimento a sus vacas, dado que no ha llovido tanto en su zona y el alimento para el ganado está muy escaso. Él sabe que solo Kiva y MiCrédito pueden brindarle esta gran oportunidad de seguir creciendo como productor agropecuario. En un futuro desea poder tener la capacidad de tener además de vacas, un criadero de cerdos.
texts.en: Juan is a fifty-one year old man. He is full of energy and love for the countryside. He is the father of four children, whom he has taught to be grateful for the land and the animals. Together, they have have prospered with their business producing basic grains and cow milk derived products. In order to give his cows good food, Juan is requesting a loan he plans to use to buy food for his cows, given that it has not rained much in the area and cattle food is very scarce. He knows that only Kiva and MiCredito can give him the great opportunity to keep on growing as an agricultural producer. In the future, he wants to have the capability of raising pigs, besides cows.

loans.use: to buy food for his cows.

loans.name: Nancy

texts.en:
This is 55-year-old Nancy. She is married and has six children, aged 38, 36, 32, 30, 28, and 18.

In 1990, Nancy established her provisions and vegetables business. Her business is located in the outskirts of Freetown, and her main customers are all classes of people. Working 6 days a week and 8 hours a day, she earns about SLL 300,000 every month from this business.

She would like a loan in the amount of SLL 5,000,000. Nancy requires a loan in order to buy more bags of Irish potatoes, carrots, onions, and some provisions for resale. She hopes that this loan will support her to increase her profit margin.

Nancy plans to educate her children up to university level and to build a house in the future. The challenges she faces in her business are financial constraints, and the cost of goods increase in the market due to inflation of prices.

She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to buy more bags of Irish potatoes, carrots, onions, and some provisions.

loans.name: Mariatu

texts.en:
This is 34-year-old Mariatu. She is married and has three children, aged 13, 8 and 6.

In 2010, Mariatu established her grocery shop business. Her business is located in the outskirts of Freetown, and her main customers are the general public. Working six days a week and 11 hours a day, she earns about SLL 1,200,000 every month from this business.

She would like a loan in the amount of SLL 5,000,000. Mariatu requires a loan in order to buy more cartons of milk, Ovaltine, tomato paste, Mega cola drinks, etc., for resale. She hopes that this loan will support her to increase her profit margin.

In the future, Mariatu plans to expand her business to a big one. The challenge she faces in her business is limited capital to expand her business. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to buy more cartons of milk, Ovaltine, tomato paste, and Mega cola drinks.

loans.name: Yaneth Del Carmen

texts.es:
Yaneth, de 38 años de edad, estudio hasta cuarto grado, está casada y su esposo se dedica a la agricultura, tiene tres hijos pero ya están acompañados y en su casa solo vive con una nieta y su esposo.

Yaneth, desde que tenía 10 años de edad, se ha dedicado al comercio, pues su mamá la mandaba a vender frescos, panes, tostadas, punches y otros productos; pero además de esos trabajos informales, también trabajo en comedores; actualmente está trabajando con una hermana en el mercado de la ciudad más cercana, en donde venden comida y para llegar a ese lugar aborda un bus que hace un recorrido de 15 kilómetros y su horario de trabajo es de 6:00 a.m. hasta las 2:30 p.m. y en su tiempo libre le ayuda a su esposo a cultivar granos básicos.


El préstamo lo necesita para comprar abono, pesticidas y herbicidas para sembrar 7,000 metros cuadrados de maíz.

Yaneth, sueña con colocar su propio comedor y poder mejorar su vivienda.
texts.en:
Yaneth is 38 years old, studied up to fourth grade, is married to her husband who is an agricultural worker and has three children, who already live with their partners. Only a granddaughter and her husband live with her.

Yaneth has worked as a trader since the age of 10, when her mother sent her to sell fresh food, bread, toast, punches and other products, but as well as this kind of informal work she also worked in cafés. She currently works with her sister in the market of the nearest city, where they sell food. She takes a 15 kilometer bus journey to get there and her working hours are from 6:00 a.m. to 2:30 p.m. In her free time she helps her husband to grow staple grains.

She needs the loan to buy fertilizer, pesticides and herbicides to sow 7,000 square meters of corn.

Yaneth dreams of buying her own café and being able to improve her home.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer, pesticides and herbicides to sow 7,000 square meters of corn.

loans.name: Rey Martir

texts.es: Don Rey se dedica a la siembra y comercialización de chayotes. Solicita un préstamo de dos mil cien dólares ($2,100), para la compra de insumos agrícolas necesarios para el desarrollo y crecimiento de dicho cultivo. De esta manera logrará incrementar la producción y mejorar los ingresos provenientes de esta actividad.
texts.en: Rey works growing and selling chayote squash. He is requesting a loan of two thousand one hundred dollars ($2,100), to buy agricultural supplies needed for the growth and development of this crop. In this way, he will be able to increase his production and improve the income he receives from this work.

loans.use: to buy supplies to grow and sell chayote squash.

loans.name: Umu Hawa

texts.en:
This is 26-year-old Hawa. She is married and has one child, aged 4. In 2008, Hawa established her cosmetics business. Her business is located in the city center, and her main customers are the general public. Working 6 days a week and 8 hours a day, she earns about SLL 700,000 every month from this business.

She would like a loan in the amount of SLL 5,000,000. Hawa requires a loan in order to purchase dozens more body creams, styling gel, different types of hair, etc. for her business. She hopes that this loan will support her to increase her profit margin.

In the future, Hawa plans to buy a plot of land, build a house, and educate her child. The challenges she faces in her business are financial constraints, and the cost of goods increase in the market due to inflation of prices.

She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to purchase dozens more body creams, styling gel, different types of hair, etc.

loans.name: Hawa

texts.en:
This is 38-year-old Hawa. She is married and has three children, aged 18, 15, and 4.

In 2000, Hawa established her grocery shop business. Her business is located in the outskirts of Freetown, and her main customers are all classes of people. Working 6 days a week and 13 hours a day, she earns about SLL 1,200,000 every month from this business.

She would like a loan in the amount of SLL 5,000,000. Hawa requires a loan in order to buy more cartons of milk, Ovaltine, tomato paste, etc. for resale. She hopes that this loan will support her to increase her profit margin.

In the future, Hawa plans to establish a big business in the area. The challenge she faces in her business is competition, which is her main challenge because other shops are located in the same area.

She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to buy more cartons of milk, Ovaltine, tomato paste, etc. for resale.

loans.name: Isata

texts.en:
This is 32-year-old Isata. She is married and has one child, aged 4. She has one additional dependent who lives with her because she helps bring him up together with her child.

In 2008, Isata established her ready-made clothes business. Her business is located in the city center, and her main customers are the general public. Working six days a week and eight hours a day, she earns about SLL 9,00,000 every month from this business.

She would like a loan in the amount of SLL 5,000,000. Isata requires a loan in order to purchase more dozens of ready-made dresses for resale. She hopes that this loan will support her to increase her profit margin.

In the future, Isata plans to educate her children up to university level. The challenges she faces in her business are financial constraints and the cost of goods increasing in the market due to inflation of prices. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to purchase dozens more ready-made dresses for resale.

loans.name: Vin's Group

texts.en: Vin’s group live in a rural village in Kandal province in Cambodia. Vin makes a living cultivating rice and she also does extra work as factory laborer and construction worker to support her family. In their village there is no reliable access to safe, clean drinking water. Having a water filter at home will help each of these women and man to safeguard the health of their families and save money on medical expenses and save time collecting fuel and boiling water.

loans.use: to buy a water filter to provide safe drinking water for their family.	.

loans.name: Shirmo

texts.ru: На фотографии запечатлена Ширмо. Она из района Вахш. Ширмо родилась и выросла в Курган Тюбинской области. Она замужем за мясника. У нее один сын. Он занимается таксистом. Ее сын взрослый и самостоятельный парень. Ширмо дома изготавливает «чакка». «Чакка» изготавливают из молока, и она молочный продукт. Ширмо изготавливает «чакка» потом продает жителем района. У нее хороший бизнес. Она хочет расширить бизнес и увеличить доход. Ей нужно денежных средств для купли молока. По этой причине Ширмо просит Вас ей помочь. Она верит в Вас.
texts.en:
This is Shirmo. She lives in the Vakhsh region. Shirmo was born and grew up in the Kurgan-Tubinsk district. She is married to a butcher. Shirmo has a n son, who works as a taxi driver.
